instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.RSMRST_L: What is RSMRST_L? RSMRST_L is an abbreviation of PM_RSMRST_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Won't Power
threads.message:
I've got a smoothie damaged board that won't boot. I'm not getting <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL> nor <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>. On <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> I need <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL>.
I'm not getting <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL>. It comes out of <TRANSISTOR>Q8151</TRANSISTOR>, but that's where I'm stuck.

For <TRANSISTOR>Q8151</TRANSISTOR> I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_1V5PGOOD</SIGNAL> coming in just fine, <CAPACITOR>C8134</CAPACITOR> is fine. <RESISTOR>R8136</RESISTOR> works fine. I'm not sure if I'm supposed to have 1.5v or 3.3v going into <TRANSISTOR>Q8151</TRANSISTOR>. When I have power running through the board there's no resistance from pin 2 to 6, and when there's no power there's no resistance from 1 to 6. But I still get no voltage coming out of 6, i.e. no <SIGNAL>DELAY_1V5S0_PGD</SIGNAL> and no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

The other half of the MOSFET is an s0 rail, so I assume we don't need it to power it on initially. Would it be safe to assume the mosfet is bad? Does that happen often?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Won't Power
threads.message:
Alright so I bridged <CAPACITOR>C8134</CAPACITOR> to <RESISTOR>R8137</RESISTOR> and it basically drops the voltage to almost nothing. Input is still 3.3v, but from <CAPACITOR>C8134</CAPACITOR> pin 2 to <RESISTOR>R8137</RESISTOR> pin 1 is almost zilch. What am I missing here?

In case this info needs to be up here, what's working:

PPBUSG3H
PP3V42
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>

I'm not getting <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>. Getting no <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> to switch on the S4 rails, put getting power for it. <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> is Power Management, Getting all the inputs except APWROK, PWROK, and <SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>. I might try what Louis did and jump PP3v42 to pin 3 on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. I'd rather not, but if I gotta.

Also I've checked for bad joins/pads, everything looks perfect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Won't Power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> assumes S0 rails are already present. If you are not even at S4 then that is the wrong place to look. 

You need s5 rails to get s4, s4 to get s3, s3 to get s0, and so on and so forth. if you don't have s5 rails then troubleshooting s0 is a waste of time.

where was the spill exactly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Won't Power
threads.message:
So the damage was mostly confined to the lower left area of the board (around the PCH and WIFI card connector) although the battery has a lot of corrosion on the board. I haven't used the battery at all. A bit of background, the board was originally worked on and "cleaned" but when I got it, it was still super dirty. I was told that at some point they got it to boot (after cleaning) but it got a kernel panic and shut off. Hasn't come back on.

I've looked all over the board and anything that looks abnormal I've tested and they work. No red pads, no missing traces, no burnt components.

Got a green then orange light on the charger, and after measuring I know I've got G3H and 3v42G3 coming in fine, both 3v and 5v S5 rails present everywhere. So since my s4 rails don't work, the schematic traces back to <CHIP>U8170</CHIP> for S4 Power Enable. Got power there too, but I have no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>.

At the PCH I don't have <SIGNAL>PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>, or <SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> going in, and they all come out of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. So do I need <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> from the SMC before I can get <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> to put out all the PWROK signals?




EDIT: Did a bit of digging, someone had pretty much the same problem as me. Even after running a wire from <CAPACITOR>C8170</CAPACITOR> to <DIODE>D8174</DIODE>, I got my 5v S4 rail going, but still no ability to power. If I do an smc bypass the computer DOES boot, so I guess the board isn't shot completely. It'll boot halfway and then reboot. Could it be a current sensing issue?


EDIT2: It's actually both s4 rails that work when i hotwire <SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, also <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET</SIGNAL>, but I can't get any s3 rails because <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> isn't coming through. Read that it could be a clock issue, <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTC</SIGNAL> reads at 32khz. I'm going nuts here.

I'm waiting for some donor boards, but I'm hoping I can find what the problem is before I gotta replace tons of components.

EDIT3: So looks like the power sequencing goes <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> -> <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> -> <SIGNAL>SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> -> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> -> <SIGNAL>RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> -> <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL>. I know I'm good up to <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, so I'll be checking <SIGNAL>SLP_SUS</SIGNAL> tomorrow. What's weird is that even with S4 rails there's no power, and an SMC bypass yields only a partial boot. Could that mean PCH damage? Or SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Won't Power
threads.message: I'm gonna take a break from this for a bit, was poking around the SMC and noticed a few components missing like <RESISTOR>R5403</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C5577</CAPACITOR>. Whoever worked on this before me did a bang up job. I'll be waiting for donor boards and will update once I can resume diagnosing. Thanks for everything!
